pr_title: OC-545 ~ Replaces custom scheduled tasks by Quartz jobs

timeline.message: OC-545 ~ Replaces custom scheduled tasks by Quartz jobs
OC-545 ~ Moves converter tests to mappers package
OC-545 ~ Adds bidirectional converter for XMLGregorianCalendar and Instant
OC-545 ~ Adds converter to mappers in ws adapters

OC-545 ~ Updates communication time check

Use java.time.Instant instead of org.joda.time.DateTime

timeline.bodyText: Any reason for using 2017 copyright with Smart Society Services B.V.?
timeline.author: bvdzwet

replies.bodyText:
Started with copy of existing class, forgot to update license header...
Updated header.
replies.author: smvdheijden

timeline.bodyText:
I was thinking about the ChronoUnit.MINUTES being hard coded and the configured value actually not being a number but a duration of time.
I don't think something should be done with this now, but maybe we can discuss the idea broader to configure such values as Duration instead of Integer. Durations can be parsed from a text in the properties file, and can be subtracted from for instance the Instant as is without having a default unit hard coded.
I don't think in practice the unit will vary much, but I like the concept of a Duration in the code as it more naturally maps to the meaning of certain fields than a plain numeric type.
timeline.author: bvdzwet

timeline.bodyText: Looking at this feels like I already reviewed this class. It looks so similar I wonder if it would not be possible to share a bit more of the communication monitoring config, instead of just duplicating it.
timeline.author: bvdzwet

replies.bodyText: Refactored the code, added JobDisabledConfig and JobEnabledConfig classes in shared.
replies.author: smvdheijden

timeline.bodyText:
I find the idea of creating one object for a log statement and an unrelated other object for actual use I bit shady.
I understand that the Instant, although fine for use to indicate a moment in time, is less pretty to use in log statements to be read by humans.
In practice these values are likely to be very close to each other (maybe even the same millisecond) but I think it would be nicer to do something like now.toDate().ToInstant() or to create the DateTime based on Instant.now(), as it feels like a more honest link between what is used and what is logged.
timeline.author: bvdzwet

replies.bodyText: Good remark, I had somehow overlooked the use of the now DateTime variable in the statemements above...
replies.author: smvdheijden

timeline.bodyText: Any reason to name the Instant date? Is this intentional or just left as-is after copy-pasting?
timeline.author: bvdzwet

timeline.bodyText:
Noting wrong with this and lately I have seen more people do this.
It just does not align with how I like to look at things and structure the code.
I like to consider the special case return value separate from the normal logic. With the else it feels like everything gets tied together in a bigger logical structure that does not need to be there.
Now this is a small method (which is good) and it does not matter that much, but there is also the level of indentation that you would not need for what comes in else now.
Just wanted to share my view, maybe even convince you, but feel free to ignore this if you like it as is.
The way null is handled here is way nicer anyway (in my opinion) than how it is handled in convertDateToXMLGregorianCalendar.
timeline.author: bvdzwet

replies.bodyText: Refactored code. (Removed the convert methods and use mapper instead)
replies.author: smvdheijden

timeline.bodyText:
It would almost have been nice had you placed a comment with this line like "Look here for the actual change". ;)
If the rest besides this (and the import that belongs with it) contains changes I should have a look at, please let me know.
timeline.author: bvdzwet

replies.bodyText: Indeed, registration of the new converter is the only change in this file...
replies.author: smvdheijden

timeline.bodyText:
Converting Instant values to XMLGregorianCalendar looks familiar from the DeviceConverterHelper, yet the implementation looks a little different.
Is the difference important, or would it be better to have more re-use of a single implementation?
Or should we wait until the story to deal with date and time helpers gets picked from the backlog?
timeline.author: bvdzwet

replies.bodyText:
Removed the convert methods from the DeviceConverterHelper.
Orika seems to contain a built-in DateToXmlGregorianCalendarConverter class and mapping between Instant and XMLGregorianCalendar couldl be done by this converter class.
replies.author: smvdheijden

timeline.bodyText:
Another pet peeve of mine. In my opinion naming test methods starting with "test" was useful when JUnit needed this to know which methods to execute as part of the test framework execution, a convention made obsolete by the Test annotation. Four characters that can be put to better use!
Just hoping to grow the community against test name duplication, if you persist in liking this naming and annotating pattern and be old school mixed with something relatively new, be my guest. ;)
timeline.author: bvdzwet

replies.bodyText: I've deactivated sonar rule S3578 on my local development environment and renamed the methods.
replies.author: smvdheijden

timeline.message:
OC-545 ~ Processes review comments - Updates job configuration

Adds generic JobDisabledConfig and JobEnabledConfig classes in order to
reduce duplicate code

OC-545 ~ Processes review comments - Refactors XMLGregorianCalendar conversion

Replaces conversion methods in DeviceConverterHelper by mapping using
* Orika built-in DateToXmlGregorianCalendarConverter
* XMLGregorianCalendarToInstantConverter
OC-545 ~ Processes review comments - Renames parameter
OC-545 ~ Processes review comments - Use same variable for logging and setter

OC-545 ~ Processes review comments - Refactors properties

Use durations instead of integers and renames properties to
maximumDurationWithoutCommunication and
minimumDurationBetweenCommunicationTimeUpdates
OC-545 ~ Processes review comments - Renames test methods
OC-545 ~ Processes some additional review comments
OC-545 ~ Prevents updating communication time when sending alarm notifications

OC-545 ~ Sets default last communication time in the future

As an attempt to improve test stability.
